description: According to news reporting originating from Winnipeg, Canada, by NewsRx correspondents, research stated,“ This joint Canadian Heart Failure Society and the CCS Heart Failure guidelines report has been developed to provide a pan-Canadian snapshot of the current state of clinic-based ambulatory heart failure care in Canada with specific reference to...
text:
2020 JUN 05 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at NewsRx
Cardiovascular Daily \-- Research findings on Heart Disorders and Diseases -
Heart Failure are discussed in a new report. According to news reporting
originating from Winnipeg, Canada, by NewsRx correspondents, research stated,
"This joint Canadian Heart Failure Society and the CCS Heart Failure
guidelines report has been developed to provide a pan-Canadian snapshot of the
current state of clinic-based ambulatory heart failure (HF) care in Canada
with specific reference to elements and processes of care associated with
quality and high performing health systems. It includes the viewpoints of
persons with lived experience, patient care providers, and administrators."

Our news editors obtained a quote from the research from the University of
Manitoba, "It is imperative to build on the themes identified in this survey,
through engaging all health care professionals, to develop integrated and
shared care models that will allow better patient outcomes. Several patient
and organizational barriers to care were identified in this survey, which must
inform the development of regional care models and pragmatic solutions to
improve transitions for this patient population. Unfortunately, we were
unsuccessful in incorporating the perspectives of primary care providers and
internal medicine specialists who provide the majority of HF care in Canada,
which in turn limits our ability to comment on strategies for capacity
building outside the HF clinic setting. These considerations must be taken
into account when interpreting our findings."

According to the news editors, the research concluded: "Engaging all HF care
providers, to build on the themes identified in this survey, will be an
important next step in developing integrated and shared care models known to
improve patient outcomes."

For more information on this research see: The Status of Specialized
Ambulatory Heart Failure Care in Canada: A Joint Canadian Heart Failure
Society and Canadian Cardiovascular Society Heart Failure Guidelines Survey.
_Cjc Open_ , 2020;2(3):151-160.

The news editors report that additional information may be obtained by
contacting S. Zieroth, University of Manitoba, Winnipeg, Manitoba, Canada.
Additional authors for this research include S.A. Virani, S. Bray, A.
Ducharme, K. Harkness, S.L. Koshman, M. McDonald, E. O'Meara, E. Swiggum, M.
Chan, J.A. Ezekowitz, N. Giannetti, A. Grzeslo, G.A. Heckman, J.G. Howlett, S.
Lepage, L. Mielniczuk and G.W. Moe.

The direct object identifier (DOI) for that additional information is:
<https://doi.org/10.1016/j.cjco.2020.03.001>. This DOI is a link to an online
electronic document that is either free or for purchase, and can be your
direct source for a journal article and its citation.

(Our reports deliver fact-based news of research and discoveries from around
the world.)

title: Researchers at University of Manitoba Discuss Findings in Heart Failure (The Status of Specialized Ambulatory Heart Failure Care in Canada: A Joint Canadian Heart Failure Society and Canadian Cardiovascular Society Heart Failure Guidelines ...): Heart Disorders and Diseases - Heart Failure
html:
2020 JUN 05 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at NewsRx Cardiovascular Daily -- Research findings on Heart Disorders and Diseases - Heart Failure are discussed in a new report. According to news reporting originating from Winnipeg, Canada, by NewsRx correspondents, research stated, “This joint Canadian Heart Failure Society and the CCS Heart Failure guidelines report has been developed to provide a pan-Canadian snapshot of the current state of clinic-based ambulatory heart failure (HF) care in Canada with specific reference to elements and processes of care associated with quality and high performing health systems. It includes the viewpoints of persons with lived experience, patient care providers, and administrators.”

Our news editors obtained a quote from the research from the University of Manitoba, “It is imperative to build on the themes identified in this survey, through engaging all health care professionals, to develop integrated and shared care models that will allow better patient outcomes. Several patient and organizational barriers to care were identified in this survey, which must inform the development of regional care models and pragmatic solutions to improve transitions for this patient population. Unfortunately, we were unsuccessful in incorporating the perspectives of primary care providers and internal medicine specialists who provide the majority of HF care in Canada, which in turn limits our ability to comment on strategies for capacity building outside the HF clinic setting. These considerations must be taken into account when interpreting our findings.”

According to the news editors, the research concluded: “Engaging all HF care providers, to build on the themes identified in this survey, will be an important next step in developing integrated and shared care models known to improve patient outcomes.”

For more information on this research see: The Status of Specialized Ambulatory Heart Failure Care in Canada: A Joint Canadian Heart Failure Society and Canadian Cardiovascular Society Heart Failure Guidelines Survey. Cjc Open, 2020;2(3):151-160.

The news editors report that additional information may be obtained by contacting S. Zieroth, University of Manitoba, Winnipeg, Manitoba, Canada. Additional authors for this research include S.A. Virani, S. Bray, A. Ducharme, K. Harkness, S.L. Koshman, M. McDonald, E. O’Meara, E. Swiggum, M. Chan, J.A. Ezekowitz, N. Giannetti, A. Grzeslo, G.A. Heckman, J.G. Howlett, S. Lepage, L. Mielniczuk and G.W. Moe.

The direct object identifier (DOI) for that additional information is: https://doi.org/10.1016/j.cjco.2020.03.001. This DOI is a link to an online electronic document that is either free or for purchase, and can be your direct source for a journal article and its citation.

(Our reports deliver fact-based news of research and discoveries from around the world.)
